title: 'install-poetry.py' throws 'ModuleNotFoundError' if 'pip' is not available.
body:
<!--

  If not, please try and fulfill these first.
-->

<!-- Checked checkbox should look like this: [x] -->
- [x] I tried to install [latest](https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/releases/latest) Poetry version.
- [x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/issues) of this repo and believe that this is not a duplicate.
- [x] There is no debug mode (`-vvv`) in `install-poetry.py`

<!--
  Once those are done, if you're able to fill in the following list with your information,
  it'd be very helpful to whoever handles the issue.
-->

- **OS version and name**: Debian 11 (Bullseye) Kernel: v5+
- **Poetry version**: v1.1.9
- **Link of a [Gist](https://gist.github.com/) with the contents of your pyproject.toml file**: _Not Required_

## Issue
<!-- Now feel free to write your issue, but please be descriptive! Thanks again ðŸ™Œ â¤ï¸ -->
The `install-poetry.py` fails after throwing Exception: `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'virtualenv'` when installing on Linux System with `pip3` present but `pip` not present.

This is not a desired behavior as this exception should be caught as `CalledProcessError` in the `Installer.install()` method.

I checked the code in `install_poetry.py`, the issue seems to be the use of `subprocess.call()` method (in `Installer.make_env()` method) instead of `subprocess.check_call()` or better instead `subprocess.run()` method (with `check=True` param).

The command invoked through `subprocess.call()` fails and the return code is non-zero too, however, it doesn't throw `CalledProcessError` exception, hence the `import virtualenv` fails later and raises `ModuleNotFoundError` exception.
